etymologies: mid 19th century (originally US, in bandwagon (sense 2)): from band + wagon

definitions: used in reference to an activity, cause, etc. that is currently fashionable or popular and attracting increasing support

examples.text: the environmental bandwagon is feeling mighty crowded
concerns over the risk posed by this emerging technology threaten to derail the bandwagon

shortDefinitions: activity or cause that has suddenly become fashionable or popular

definitions: (especially formerly) a wagon used for carrying a band in a parade or procession

examples.text: the colorful bandwagon was later purchased for use in circus parades

shortDefinitions: wagon used for carrying band in parade or procession
